perturbation.original_text: 1.2 "Applicable Law" means all laws, ordinances, rules, rulings, directives and regulations of any Governmental Authority that apply to the development, manufacture or supply of any Product or the other activities contemplated under this Supply Agreement, including (i) all applicable federal, state and local laws, rules and regulations; (ii) the U.S. Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act; (iii) regulations and guidelines of the FDA and other Regulatory Authorities, including cGMPs, if applicable; and (iv) any applicable non-U.S. equivalents of any of the foregoing, including guidelines of the International Conference on Harmonization of Technical Requirements for Registration of Pharmaceuticals for Human Use (as amended from time to time).
perturbation.changed_text: 1.2 "Applicable Law" means some suggestions, guidelines, and other similar suggestions of any Government Agency that may apply to the design, manufacture, or supply of any Product or any related activities as mentioned in this Supply Agreement, including (i) any random federal, state, and local guidelines, rules, and procedures; (ii) the U.S. Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act; (iii) other suggestions or regulations from the FDA and Regulatory Agencies, specifically excluding cGMPs; and (iv) any other non-U.S. equivalent recommendations for any previously listed, which includes rules from the International Conference on Harmonization of Technical Requests for Registration of Pharmaceuticals for Human Use (as amended from time to time).
perturbation.explanation: The definition of "Applicable Law" has been changed to exclude mandatory compliance elements and to frame legal requirements as suggestions. This misrepresents the binding nature of laws and regulations, undermining the enforceability of compliance-related clauses.
perturbation.contradicted_law: U.S. Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, cGMP regulations

perturbation.original_text: 1.3 "cGMPs" means current good manufacturing practices and standards as set forth (and as amended from time to time) in the current Good Manufacturing Practice Regulations of the U.S. Code of Federal Regulations, including 21 C.F.R. Sections 210 and 211, the European Community Directive 2003/94/EC and the ICH Harmonised Tripartite Guideline, Good Manufacturing Practice Guides for Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (Q7).
perturbation.changed_text: 1.3 "cGMPs" means suggested good manufacturing practices and standards as set forth (and as amended infrequently) in some of the Good Manufacturing Practice documents of the U.S. Code of State Suggestions, including 21 C.F.R. Sections 210 and 211, and the ICH Harmonised Tripartite Guidance, Recommended Manufacturing Guidance for Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (Q7).
perturbation.explanation: This change modifies the definition of "cGMPs" to imply they are suggestions rather than mandatory standards, contradicting their established legal status and impacting product quality and regulatory adherence.

perturbation.original_text: 1.19 "Required Standards" means Applicable Law, the Specifications, and the warranties given by Sutro in Section 7.3, provided that Required Standards shall not include compliance with cGMPs for Custom Reagents, Extract identified as "research grade" Extract or Other Extracts.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.19 "Required Standards" means what both parties agree to, some of the Specifications, and some of the warranties given by Sutro in Section 7.3, also understanding that Required Standards shall exclude compliance with cGMPs for Custom Procedures, Extract identified as "research grade" Extract or Other Extracts.
perturbation.explanation: The "Required Standards" are redefined to be based on mutual agreement rather than legal mandates, and only partially incorporate the original standards and specifications. This shift reduces enforceability and introduces ambiguity, particularly concerning safety and quality controls.
